comments:
I'm observing a crash about once every two hours that appears to occur whilst
scrolling, either using a scroll bar, mouse wheel or shifting a cursor with
arrow keys.

I'm using a JBoss IDE build, reporting Eclipse SDK Version 3.1.2,
build id M20060118-1600.

The OS platform is Fedora Core 6 Linux with kernal 2.6.20 for x86_64.
The machine has dual core Intel CPUs and has been stable for everything
else I've used it for in the week since I've had it.

Not sure where to find any stack traces or diagnostic output after
a crash.

Perhaps this has been fixed in subsequent releases?

There should be logs not only in your workspace/.metadata/.log but in the directory from which you launched eclipse as well.  These ones are VM logs and are the most interesting in this case.  If you can find them (they're usually one long timestamp with .log appended) and attach them here we can proceed.  Without them we can't go any further.

Here is what I collected from another crash.  I ran eclipse from a terminal and there was no <longTimestamp>.log in the directory from which I ran the process.
The <workspace>/.metadata/.log file entries all predated the crash by a couple of hours.

Passing to SWT for comment.

For what its worth, I've since observed this crash whilst selecting text with
the mouse, not just when scrolling.  Still haven't managed to find any other
log/diagnostic output beyond the sort already provided after other crashes.

Crashing about every 2-3 hours, auto-save set to 1 minute :-(
I'm somewhat tempted to install the latest stable eclipse to
see if the issue occurs there, but need to find out whether the project
I'm working on requires anything JBoss specific since that seems to have
been mandated locally.

Daniel, after taking a quick look at the JBoss page, it seems to me that there are no downloads available with the 64-bit version of Eclipse. The only options presented to the user for Linux are: Linux/GTK x86. You can take a look by going to Help>About Eclipse SDK>Configuration Details. Take a look to see what the arch line is (it should be something like x86_64).

So my question to you : when you installed JBoss did you download the entire IDE + Eclipse, or did you just download the JBoss plugins and install in on top of a 64 bit Eclipse? If you did option 1 you might want to give option 2 a try.

Also, if you locate the directory where your eclipse executable resides all crash logs should be in there. They are named either hs_err_pid[number].log or javacore.[date].[time].[number].txt.
In fact, you should get the latest Eclipse 3.3 M7 nightly and let us know if the problem had gone away, even if you don't end up switching to it.

I've installed Eclipse 3.2.2 and the Sun's linux 64bit JDK for AMD but still getting crashes (I assume from the same problem, it may be something else) - the top my Eclipse configuration info looks like the following.  I am happy to install a nightly build sometime next week - I've just had a rather critical project running behind schedule so I haven't had time to futz about with this problem too much, just putting up with regular crashes.

I also installed Sun's latest Java 6 update 1 JDK for linux AMD (64 bit).
Here are some diagnostics I collected, couldn't find any crash logs
(hs_err_pid[number].log or javacore.[date].[time].[number].txt though).
Let me know if you need any further info.

Regards,

Daniel

Created an attachment (id=68317)
Eclipse 3.3RC1 Configuration Details

Here's my current configuration details from Eclipse in case that is useful.

Daniel

I am attaching a .options file which will allow you to (hopefully) get some more info from the error message you get when you crash.

To use it:

1. Copy the .options file to your Eclipse install directory.

2. Start up Eclipse from the command line:

./eclipse -debug (plus whatever other options you normally set)


3. You should see a bunch of verbose startup messages in the console. Keep an eye out for the following line which indicates that the .options file got picked up:

[Verbose start up]
Debug options:
    file:[eclipse install directory]/.options loaded


4. Proceed as normal and paste any results you get from a crash back here.

Created an attachment (id=68438)
.options file

Another crash, this time I resulting in a hs_err_pid4197.log thankfully.
I have no idea if this is related to the previous issues reported in this
bug report.  I note the hs_err_pid4197.log suggests submitting a bug
report to Sun, I guess that is probably worthwhile.  Maybe this makes
you guys less worried about Eclipse and more concerned about the quality
of the AMD 64-bit linux JVM.  With crashes throughout the day, I am
starting to get tempted to migrate my development to Windows in the
hope that there is greater stability (did I really say that :-( ).

Here is some more info from this crash, I'll attach hs_err_pid4197.log shortly for what its worth:

> migrate my development to Windows 

Let's try and fix you first.  Have you tried changing your theme?  There were problems (way back when) with Blue Curve.  Also, comment #8 includes an X error.  Do you always get this when you crash?

Unfortunately, the VM was unable to print the full stack so we don't have the method where the crash was occurring.

OK - I was working on getting you a custom SWT jar to try with the possible offending code indicated in Comment #12 commented out. However, the crash you attached points in a completely different area of Eclipse. The one common element between both crash logs is the "Xlib: resource ID allocation space exhausted!" message which indicates a resource leak. Are you still using JBoss IDE or just straight Eclipse? I'd like to get exactly the same configuration that you are running and see what happens after a few hours. Please let me know:

- Eclipse version
- JBoss version
- GTK, Pango, Cairo, ATK, and Glib2 versions -typs the following in a terminal:
rpm -q gtk2 pango cairo atk glib2

I'm just using a plain Eclipse build, JBoss is not involved.

> Have you tried changing your theme?  There were problems (way back

Yeah, I read about those.  I haven't changed themes thus far, have been
using the default theme "Clearlooks".  I've just changed to the "Mist"
theme to see if it makes any difference.

>  Also, comment #8 includes an X
> error.  Do you always get this when you crash?

Funny you ask that, I just experienced another crash only minutes ago
and saw:
 Xlib: resource ID allocation space exhausted!
 *** glibc detected *** /usr/java/jdk1.6.0_01/bin/java: munmap_chunk():
  invalid pointer: 0x00002aaaabb430a2 ***
printed to the console.  I couldn't guarantee that it always occurs.
In support of a leak issue, a crash is usually not observed until after
an hour or so from starting the eclipse process.

I googled around a bit to see what came up for the message "Xlib: resource ID allocation space exhausted!" which seems to be prevalent in all of your crashes so  far.

It seems that some people who have had the same message had success when switching video drivers. The other thing I saw mentioned was making sure that the XC-MISC extension is loaded. 

To check this out, run xdpyinfo in a terminal and see if its listed in the modules section (near the beginning of the output). If it is not, you can try to add this line in your xorg.conf file, in the "Module" section:
        Load  "extmod"

Thanks for the suggestions, I'm going to work through them one by one
to see check out each individually, which may take some time.

After having changed themes to the Glider theme, things may have
gotten better, but it is probably too early to say.  I had things
go unresponsive for me yesterday at least once during an svn
commit/update, but that may be to do with the subclipse plugin.

So I'll monitor things with the new theme for another day or so to
see if that has worked around the problem.  If not, I'll give
the XC-MISC extension a whirl, as I am not currently running that.
Then switch video drivers if I still have no success - currently
running an nvidia driver after the default nv driver proved to be
a bit flakey.

Thanks for the responses, I'll let you know how it goes.

Maybe my configuration just needs more memory than allowed by default??

This looks like a different error message from what you were getting before. Passing the -XX:MaxPermSize=128M flag on the command line should provide enough space for base eclipse. If you are using lots of other plugins on top of Eclipse, you might need to increment that number.
